item.title: [SPR-1160] Using deprecated oracle class/package in the reference documentation
item.description:
According to the latest oracle jdbc driver release note (http://www.oracle.com/technology/software/tech/java/sqlj_jdbc/htdocs/readme_10201.html), the use of oracle.jdbc.driver package has been deprecated, but the reference manual example has a reference to it.

http://static.springframework.org/spring/docs/1.2.x/reference/jdbc.html
item.summary: Using deprecated oracle class/package in the reference documentation

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The link you gave doesn't seem to work...

In any case, the only mentioning of an Oracle package in the entire JDBC chapter is the driver class name "oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver". That's hardly an issue, in particular as this should work just fine on 10g as well, and is the only way to specify the driver for older Oracle driver versions (which are still very common).

Maybe we can put a comment there, pointing out that the recommended driver class name is different as of Oracle 10g.

Juergen

I didn't think it's a big deal either but just saw this while going through the readme and figured it wouldn't hurt to file the issue here (hence the trivial priority).

Here's the correct link.
www.oracle.com/technology/software/tech/java/sqlj_jdbc/htdocs/readme_10201.html

In case it doesn't work again, i am copying the section of interest.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

The Old oracle.jdbc.driver Package Will Go Away !!!
---------------------------------------------------

Beginning in Oracle 9i, Oracle extensions to JDBC are captured in
the package oracle.jdbc. This package contains classes and
interfaces that specify the Oracle extensions in a manner similar
to the way the classes and interfaces in java.sql specify the
public JDBC API.

The use of the package oracle.jdbc.driver has been deprecated
since the initial version of 9i. Your code should use the package
oracle.jdbc instead. New features since Oracle 9i are incompatible
with use of the package oracle.jdbc.driver. Although we continue
to support the old package oracle.jdbc.driver in this release to
provide backwards compatibility, the package will definitely be
removed in the next major release. If you still have existing
applications that use the old oracle.jdbc.driver package, now is the
time to convert your code.

All that is required to covert your code is to replace
"oracle.jdbc.driver" with "oracle.jdbc" in the source and recompile.
This cannot be done piecewise. You must convert all classes
and interfaces that are referenced by an application.

OK, thanks for the clarification. The link now worked: I see that the "oracle.jdbc.driver" package has already been deprecated since Oracle 9i. I initially got the impression it has just been deprecated as of 10g R2.

Consequently, I have changed the driver class name in the JDBC chapter to "oracle.jdbc.OracleDriver", which should work on both Oracle 9i and 10g.

Juergen
